BUSINESS STAFF
MAKES SURVEY
The Business Staff of the
NEWS-LETTER is taking a survey of the purchasing habits
of the Johns Hopkins student
body. The purpose of this
survey is to prove to the advertisers by statistics of the
improvement in sales they derive by advertising in the
college publications. A number of men will be interviewed
to find out facts about where,
when and how often they buy
their various necessities. It
is hoped that sufficient data
can be obtained to give an
accurate result.

DR. TURNER
FrHE University has suffered a great loss through the passing of Dr.
± Edward Raymond Turner, professor of European history. Dr.
Turner's authoritative works on all phases of European history from
1450 to the present day won for him world-wide recognition and so
reflected honor upon the institution with which he was connected.
Dr. Turner's death holds a peculiar significance to the undergraduate at Hopkins, for it was the unanimous opinion of the student
body that he was the best lecturer in the college. We use the word
unanimously" in its literal sense, for we have never heard of anyone
disagreeing with this view. Dr. Turner combined all the essential
qualities of a brilliant speaker. First and foremost, he made his audience interested in his topic. Through the medium of his expression
one saw men and events moving as if in real life; one was eager to
learn the outcome of the great events which were unfolded before him.
In addition Dr. Turner made his students appreciate the importance of
even the most seemingly insignificant and recondite details. Such was
the continuity of Dr. Turner's story of history that his students felt
that the life of the twentieth century is a direct result of the happenings in distant throne-rooms of the past. He caused his students to
feel that each one as an individual was leading a life made possible only
through a definite sequence of events, leading back into long-gone
years. This feeling of "personal relationship with history," if we
may so designate it, was caused partially by the stress which Dr. Turner
put upon non-political history, but its real cause was the intense earnestness, the vision, the vitality of the lecturer. Dr. Turner did not appear to his students as a man who merely studied history; he seemed to
live it. The intense love of the historical flowed from the professor to
the student. Many men know their subject; a very small minority are
able to teach it; a very few can interest their students in it. Dr.
Turner was a member of all three classes.

AMBITION
T

AST Saturday the Triangle Club of Princeton University paid its
annual visit to Baltimore, producing "The Golden Dog" at the
Lyric. This musical comedy of old Quebec was written, produced, and
acted by undergraduates with one exception of a faculty coach. The
production was particularly interesting to college men as an example
of the excellence of undergraduate activities.
We are far too prone at Hopkins to judge the merit of each extracurricular activity solely in comparison to what has been done in previous years. When we say that "this is a good Hullabaloo," or "a
good NEWS-LETTER" we mean that the publication is good as compared with the issues of the past few years. We neglect the fact that
there is room for great improvement over anything that has been done
in the past.
The Barnstormers have certainly not deteriorated in the past few
years. Their productions are still very enjoyable, they continue to maintain their high place in student activities. But an exhibition such as
the Triangle Club gave serves to point out the fact that much greater
things could be done with the aid of a little ambition and a great deal
of hard work. Of course, no one expects a college of 800 students to
watch the production of a college such as Princeton, but the attempt
could be made.
We firmly believe that should the Barnstormers attempt a production
such as "The Golden Dog" that it would prove a failure. But the
next attempt would not be so bad, the succeeding ones a little better,
and in the space of a few years we should see the Barnstormers producing plays that are far superior to those of today.
The difficulty lies in making the start. Each man when he becomes
head of an activity is determined that his charge shall not be
debased during his term of office. And so he shies at any substantial innovations. Certainly he cannot be blamed for his conservatism;
he is interested in the future of his activity, but his primary objective
lies in maintaining the excellence of that activity which he is still actively connected with it. So there is grave doubt that we shall ever have a
Barnstormers Club composed of members who are willing to risk a
bad production solely for the future advancement of the activity. Nor
do these remarks apply solely to the Barnstormers. They may be applied equally as well to every activity at Homewood with the exception
of the lacrosse team. The lacrosse team aims at the highest perch and
it is the only undergraduate activity at Hopkins that does so.

Homewood Play Shop
Presents Plays
The initial play series of the
Homewood Play Shop was presented last Monday at the association's stage on the Hopkins campus.
The two productions interpreted
were "The Garroters" and "Bride
Roses," both by William Dean
Howells. These productions will
also be enacted' on January the
ninth, tenth and eleventh. The
casts in the main have been selected
from the English Drama students

DEBATING TRIP
(Cont. from page 1. col. 1)

R. 0. T. C. Officers Club
Adopts Constitution
The second meeting of the newly
formed Officers Club was held last
Monday before drill. The principal
object of the meeting was to act
upon the constitution which had
been drawn up by a group formed
for that purpose.
•
The minutes of the previous
meeting were read by the Secretary
and adopted. The Constitution was
then read in full. After some discussion it was adopted without
amendments. Among its prominent features are provisions for the
automatic election of all cadet
officers, and that the head of the
unit automatically becomes the
President of the club. The VicePresident and Secretary-Treasurer
are to be elected.

•

Teams of four men each will
represent their respective departments. A dance or dinner, no doubt,
will be held after the final matches
at which time the victorious team
will receive its award.

the Committee has limited students
entering the contest to those pursuing graduate courses in the day
school. Night school students are
not eligible in the competition. Any
member of the faculty no matter
what classes he teaches may enter
the contest, nor is the eligibility of
these faculty members dependent
on their having Ph.D. degrees.
It is not too late for departments
who have not entered the contest
to do so. Every graduate department is strongly urged to appoint
its representatives without further
delay.

Four lectures, according to the
President's office, have been scheduled at the Civil Engineering auditorium immediately following the
Christmas holidays. Three are to
be delivered by virtue of the James
Schouler Foundation, while the
International Relations Club is
sponsoring a fourth.
On January the eighth, and tenth,
respectively F. A. Bland, professor
at the University of Sydney will
discourse on "White Australia; Its
Policy and Aims" and "Government
Enterprises and Their efficiency"
at 5 P. M. in the C. E. Hall. "The
Greek Refuge Problem" will be
the subject of the Hon. Henry
Morgenthau, former minister to
Turkey who will conclude the
Foundation dissertations on January, the seventeenth.
The International Relations Club
will be Dr. Tibor Eckhardt,
speaker

TWO DANCES
Resuming its activities after the
Christmas Recess, the Graduate
Students' Club will sponsor its first
tea dance of the New Year on
Thursday afternoon. The dance
will be held in Levering Hall and
will last from four to six.
Heretofore, these dances have
been held on Wednesday afternoons, but those in charge wished
to make it possible for students
with seminars on that day to
attend; therefore future dances of
this type will be on Thursday afternoon.
An evening dance for the Graduate Students is planned for the third
week in this month on a Friday
evening. It is hoped that a large
number will support the affair.
The Graduate Inter-Departmental Bowling Contest will begin the
second week in January. The
various departments who have
signified their intention of competing have appointed official representatives for arranging the contest.
These men are as follows:
Economics, Joseph Blandi; English, Clark Wisotski; History,
Geoge Dorsey; Political Science,
M. Spaulding.
In all probability the faculty will
also enter a team in the contest
though no representative has as yet
been appointed. The winning team
will be awarded a cup at the conclusion of the competition while the
team having the lowest score will
receive a "booby" prize.

In the Bell System research and development
are not confined to engineering laboratory. These
methods are applied also to
the commercial side of the
business, to make telephone service more
and more useful.
An example is the classified telephone directory, with its convenient listings by trade

and profession, for quick and easy reference.
Or take this other use of the classified
directory. Telephone men analyzed advertising and merchandising. They saw that prospective purchasers of advertised products
often did not know where to buy them.They
developed a plan for listing these dealers
under their brand name in local "Where to
Buy It" directories — a genuine service to
buyer and seller alike.

Vol. XXXIV, No. 23

BUSINESS STAFF
MAKES SURVEY
The Business Staff of the
NEWS-LETTER is taking a survey of the purchasing habits
of the Johns Hopkins student
body. The purpose of this
survey is to prove to the advertisers by statistics of the
improvement in sales they derive by advertising in the
college publications. A number of men will be interviewed
to find out facts about where,
when and how often they buy
their various necessities. It
is hoped that sufficient data
can be obtained to give an
accurate result.

DR. TURNER
FrHE University has suffered a great loss through the passing of Dr.
± Edward Raymond Turner, professor of European history. Dr.
Turner's authoritative works on all phases of European history from
1450 to the present day won for him world-wide recognition and so
reflected honor upon the institution with which he was connected.
Dr. Turner's death holds a peculiar significance to the undergraduate at Hopkins, for it was the unanimous opinion of the student
body that he was the best lecturer in the college. We use the word
unanimously" in its literal sense, for we have never heard of anyone
disagreeing with this view. Dr. Turner combined all the essential
qualities of a brilliant speaker. First and foremost, he made his audience interested in his topic. Through the medium of his expression
one saw men and events moving as if in real life; one was eager to
learn the outcome of the great events which were unfolded before him.
In addition Dr. Turner made his students appreciate the importance of
even the most seemingly insignificant and recondite details. Such was
the continuity of Dr. Turner's story of history that his students felt
that the life of the twentieth century is a direct result of the happenings in distant throne-rooms of the past. He caused his students to
feel that each one as an individual was leading a life made possible only
through a definite sequence of events, leading back into long-gone
years. This feeling of "personal relationship with history," if we
may so designate it, was caused partially by the stress which Dr. Turner
put upon non-political history, but its real cause was the intense earnestness, the vision, the vitality of the lecturer. Dr. Turner did not appear to his students as a man who merely studied history; he seemed to
live it. The intense love of the historical flowed from the professor to
the student. Many men know their subject; a very small minority are
able to teach it; a very few can interest their students in it. Dr.
Turner was a member of all three classes.

AMBITION
T

AST Saturday the Triangle Club of Princeton University paid its
annual visit to Baltimore, producing "The Golden Dog" at the
Lyric. This musical comedy of old Quebec was written, produced, and
acted by undergraduates with one exception of a faculty coach. The
production was particularly interesting to college men as an example
of the excellence of undergraduate activities.
We are far too prone at Hopkins to judge the merit of each extracurricular activity solely in comparison to what has been done in previous years. When we say that "this is a good Hullabaloo," or "a
good NEWS-LETTER" we mean that the publication is good as compared with the issues of the past few years. We neglect the fact that
there is room for great improvement over anything that has been done
in the past.
The Barnstormers have certainly not deteriorated in the past few
years. Their productions are still very enjoyable, they continue to maintain their high place in student activities. But an exhibition such as
the Triangle Club gave serves to point out the fact that much greater
things could be done with the aid of a little ambition and a great deal
of hard work. Of course, no one expects a college of 800 students to
watch the production of a college such as Princeton, but the attempt
could be made.
We firmly believe that should the Barnstormers attempt a production
such as "The Golden Dog" that it would prove a failure. But the
next attempt would not be so bad, the succeeding ones a little better,
and in the space of a few years we should see the Barnstormers producing plays that are far superior to those of today.
The difficulty lies in making the start. Each man when he becomes
head of an activity is determined that his charge shall not be
debased during his term of office. And so he shies at any substantial innovations. Certainly he cannot be blamed for his conservatism;
he is interested in the future of his activity, but his primary objective
lies in maintaining the excellence of that activity which he is still actively connected with it. So there is grave doubt that we shall ever have a
Barnstormers Club composed of members who are willing to risk a
bad production solely for the future advancement of the activity. Nor
do these remarks apply solely to the Barnstormers. They may be applied equally as well to every activity at Homewood with the exception
of the lacrosse team. The lacrosse team aims at the highest perch and
it is the only undergraduate activity at Hopkins that does so.

R. 0. T. C. Officers Club
Adopts Constitution
The second meeting of the newly
formed Officers Club was held last
Monday before drill. The principal
object of the meeting was to act
upon the constitution which had
been drawn up by a group formed
for that purpose.
•
The minutes of the previous
meeting were read by the Secretary
and adopted. The Constitution was
then read in full. After some discussion it was adopted without
amendments. Among its prominent features are provisions for the
automatic election of all cadet
officers, and that the head of the
unit automatically becomes the
President of the club. The VicePresident and Secretary-Treasurer
are to be elected.

Greek Refuge Problem" will be

Morgenthau, former minister to
Turkey who will conclude the
Foundation dissertations on January, the seventeenth.

will be Dr. Tibor Eckhardt,

TWO DANCES
Resuming its activities after the
Christmas Recess, the Graduate
Students' Club will sponsor its first
tea dance of the New Year on
Thursday afternoon. The dance
will be held in Levering Hall and
will last from four to six.
Heretofore, these dances have
been held on Wednesday afternoons, but those in charge wished
to make it possible for students
with seminars on that day to
attend; therefore future dances of
this type will be on Thursday afternoon.
An evening dance for the Graduate Students is planned for the third
week in this month on a Friday
evening. It is hoped that a large
number will support the affair.
The Graduate Inter-Departmental Bowling Contest will begin the
second week in January. The
various departments who have
signified their intention of competing have appointed official representatives for arranging the contest.
These men are as follows:
Economics, Joseph Blandi; English, Clark Wisotski; History,
Geoge Dorsey; Political Science,
M. Spaulding.
In all probability the faculty will
also enter a team in the contest
though no representative has as yet
been appointed. The winning team
will be awarded a cup at the conclusion of the competition while the
team having the lowest score will
receive a "booby" prize.

In the Bell System research and development
are not confined to engineering laboratory. These
methods are applied also to
the commercial side of the
business, to make telephone service more
and more useful.
An example is the classified telephone directory, with its convenient listings by trade

and profession, for quick and easy reference.
Or take this other use of the classified
directory. Telephone men analyzed advertising and merchandising. They saw that prospective purchasers of advertised products
often did not know where to buy them.They
developed a plan for listing these dealers
under their brand name in local "Where to
Buy It" directories — a genuine service to
buyer and seller alike.
